plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub prized for its large, showy flowers that bloom in winter to early spring. Camellias have glossy dark green leaves and produce rose-like blooms in shades of white, pink, or red.
plants.location: Eastern Asia (cultivated globally, especially in temperate zones)
plants.funFact: Some Camellia japonica flowers have up to 90 petals, making them extremely full and lush compared to many other flowers.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A perennial plant known for its winter-blooming white to pink flowers appearing in the cold months, often pushing through snow. It grows low to the ground with leathery green leaves.
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas Rose is not a true rose; it belongs to the buttercup family (Ranunculaceae).

plants.name: Campsis radicans
plants.description: A vigorous, woody vine famed for its trumpet-shaped, bright orange to red flowers that attract hummingbirds. In warmer climates, it can bloom into the cooler months or start early in mild winters.
plants.bloomingSeason: June to September in temperate climate, but in warmer southern US areas can have sporadic blooms in winter including January.
plants.location: Southeastern United States (native) and cultivated in warmer temperate zones
plants.funFact: Trumpet Creeper flowers are pollinated primarily by hummingbirds, which are attracted to their bright color and tubular shape.

plants.name: Banksia ericifolia
plants.description: An Australian native shrub with spiky, bright flower spikes that bloom in winter. It features narrow, needle-like leaves and orange to red flower clusters that are a nectar source for native birds.
plants.funFact: Banksias produce large amounts of nectar and are important food sources for birds and mammals during the Australian winter months.
